subject: RE: [junit] Preventing JUnit from stopping on failures.
msgSnippet: I ll repeat what I said earlier.  JUnit probably is not the right tool for what you need to do.  You are trying to chop down trees with a scalpel. Look at Fit
messageBody:
I'll repeat what I said earlier. JUnit probably is not the right tool for
what you need to do. You are trying to chop down trees with a scalpel.

Look at Fit and/or Fitnesse. These are designed for just the tests you
describe, and do not stop on a failed check (their concept for assertion).

Good luck.

--
Jim McMaster
mailto:jim.mcmaster@...

Raffael Housler
Sent: Tuesday, August 23, 2005 3:36 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Preventing JUnit from stopping on failures.


I appreciate the input but I dont think I was clear enough...

This is a large scale project in which it is completely unfeasible to find a
single error per test, fix it, and run the test again. This is mainly
because most of the things that are being tested are NOT DIRECTLY related.
Let me give you a brief example:

Prep: Robot Clicks "Activate Thermoflater" button
Assert: Does textfield1 match textfield1.bmp
Assert: Does textfield1 text match "blah blah"
Assert: Does label1 match jlabel1.bmp
Assert: Is popup visible
etc

Now hopefully you understand why all assertions must be executed; otherwise
if it fails on the first assertion, firstly there is not enough information
pin point the problem on the jtextfield or the input mechanism etc and we
would also not know if the rest of them are correct until this one was
fixed, recompiled, and retested (very long time on large scale projects like
this).

So the ideal is, it runs through it, lists all the failures and the problem
can be diagnosed with much greater accuracy and speed (less time). Time is
the key.

The tests become quite complex, and it would be possible to write a seperate
test for each component, however there would be a huge excess of redundant
code (lost time).
